ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The second semester definitely had a broader emphasis on group course work such as debates and other presentations on really niche science topics, so I'd say my communication skills and cram research skills improved.
I learned about current topics in science
I learned about exoplanets, cosmology, virology, and many other topics that are relevant in the world of science today. This course provided a general overview of different fields in modern science.
I know what a hierarchical cluster analysis is. I know a little bit more about biology and viruses.

I learned some basic information about a few different areas that are currently of interest in science. The professors for each module frequently went into pretty complicated explanations of certain topics within the module, but the pace was often too fast to understand anything easily. I managed to do decently well in the course and complete all the quizzes, problem sets, projects, etc. but I did not learn as much as I hoped I would. I kind of just got through the class without learning very much. Maybe in-person, as opposed to on Zoom due to the pandemic, it would be better. I don't know for sure though.
Extremely broad variety of current topics in science.

This course covers a variety of topics of interest across several fields of study. These include: cosmology, human cloning, virology, and the scientific method. The modules gave me a broad framework for thinking about fields that I was not familiar with before. The topics were also relevant to contemporary issues. The module on virology, for example, helped me understand how and why the Coronavirus pandemic unfolded as it did. I also learned quantitative skills, such as finding the degree of proximity between data points using hierarchical clustering.
I gained a variety of introductory insights into multiple fields of science.
I learned in-depth information about numerous topics important to science in our modern world.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
strengths
-few ppl in the class so it's easier to get to know your peers
-low time commitment for work and class meetings
-wide variety of science topics
weaknesses
-pure lecture for first two sessions (each session is 1.5 hours)
-can get boring pretty easily

Strengths: Professor Kankel was nice. 
Weaknesses: Grading was arbitrary, had no idea what going on half of the time, certain professors graded modules extremely hard for no reason, modules weren't as interesting as I thought they'd be. However, in the end it ended up being fine.

This course was a pretty low workload and an easy way to get a science credit out of the way during your first year. Each of the modules had a different professor so it was kind of hit or miss for each topic. In the end, the grading was pretty generous, but the grading of each module seemed highly arbitrary and inconsistent, perhaps because each was led by a different professor. The problem sets and quizzes could also be better spaced out, perhaps by having the problem set due by the second meeting of the module and leave the quiz for the last session.
More organization and assignments that have more relationship with the course content.

Strengths: some topics in the course can be interesting, it is a laid-back first year seminar and science credit, you get to study a little bit about a wide range of science topics, and each module is taught by a different professor. 
Weaknesses: very low engagement is required to do well in the class and it is generally hard to stay engaged with the class; the structure of the class is flawed because the three-week modules don't give professors enough time to teach in-depth, which often resulted in almost every student in the class being confused and lost after lectures; the classes are long (hour and a half) and only meets once a week on Friday afternoons  maybe two fifty-minute sessions per week would be better.

Did not like the idea of a two-semester course binding, but it was interesting to change topics every 3 weeks and keep the course fresh. Grading was also very vague and we did not even receive our first grades back until midway through the second semester of the course.

The strength of this course was the wide scope of material that it covered in a short span of time. The lectures were structured so as to succinctly introduce the fundamental aspects of various fields of study, without going too far into potentially-confusing mathematical and biological details. The professor was always willing to provide additional guidance and clarification, so I never felt lost in the course. The workload in the course was higher than I had anticipated, though, as there was usually a quiz, problem set, and presentation due every third week. If you spread out the work, however, these assignments are manageable.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The presentations over zoom were very nice, and the professors always recorded the lectures and posted lecture material on canvas which was extremely lovely; however, because the lectures are on a computer, fairly long, and have very little interactive components, it was very easy to zone out.

The recording of each session was very helpful in completing the problem set and preparing for the quiz in each module. When we had debates, the format was pretty rigid and I would have enjoyed it more if the debate was more fluid and students could jump in and out of conversation.
N/A

In general, having this course on Zoom was tough. I imagine and hope the course would be better in person. There were not any really specific practices geared towards learning during Covid-19; I imagine the course was run how it normally would be run, except that everything was on Zoom and not in-person, and that quizzes were done online rather than in-person. The quizzes were perfectly fine in how they were handled.

Maintaining a level of engagement via Zoom was not always easy. At times, the course felt more like a lecture that a seminar. Every third week, however, there was an opportunity for student engagement in the form of a required presentation. I personally prefer listening to talking, so the format suited me quite well. Someone who expects regular class discussions might not feel as engaged as I did, however.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Really great gut science course that covers a whole bunch of niche topics; can get boring pretty easily tho on lecture days
I think this is one of the best ways to get a science credit at Yale. If you do the work, you will get an A or A-.

If you want a science credit done by the end of your first year, are looking for a half credit to tack on each semester, and are willing to sit through some pretty boring material, then yes. Also, this class is technically labeled a seminar, but it is really a lecture course with student involvement once every three weeks.

I honestly don't know what to think of this course -- whether it was easy or hard, good or bad. I don't feel like I took away a ton of content but it did inspire me to look into future courses in certain areas of science.

I probably would not recommend this course to another student, especially if they aren't able to get another first-year seminar in addition to this one. I was lucky to get another first-year seminar in the fall, which I really enjoyed. If I had had to pick between this seminar and the other, and had chosen this one, I would have kicked myself for it by the end of the year because my other first-year seminar was awesome and this one simply was not. I took it to get a science credit, so at least I got that, but even so I feel like there must be other science credits for non-STEM majors in which you can get the credit without too much stress but still learn something and be engaged with the class. I did not learn as much as I wished in this class and I was not very engaged. Part of that was certainly my fault, but the class definitely didn't facilitate learning and engagement as well as it could have. I just wasn't very excited to go to class. Maybe it's a lot better in person as opposed to on Zoom during Covid, but I can't be sure. On the positive, the workload is very very light so if you have four credits already and want to add a half credit to each semester, it might be a good class to take for that reason. Be aware, though, that in order to earn credit for this class, you have to take it for the entire year (both semesters), and you only get one credit total  half a credit per semester.
I think this course would be much better as an in-person seminar, would not suggest if it stays online.

I would recommend this course to another student with an interest in the STEM fields. A basic familiarity with biological concepts definitely helps in understanding the material. But even if you come in with little biological knowledge, as I did, you can read up on the fundamental biological aspects between modules and still be successful. Be prepared to put in some work into preparing presentations and studying for quizzes. These assignments are not too difficult, but should better not be put off to the last moment. You'll come out of this course feeling like you can hold an informed conversation on topics you might have never thought about (such as the age and composition of the universe).
I would certainly recommend this course as a first year seminar in a low stress setting. Very happy with how the year went.
Yes, because much of the material is very relevant to the modern world.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: N/a
N/A

This was a First-Year Seminar with only eleven students, but it was more a combination of lectures and seminar discussions. Over the course of the full year, there were eight 3-week modules (four modules per semester). Each of these modules essentially consisted of lectures for the first two weeks, and then on the third week, the class would take a more seminar-type style. The third week of each module usually consisted of a debate or project presentations.
Some classes dedicated to debates or presentations.
A combination of virtual lectures and student presentations.
